newsitem.title: USA: Toyota US output unaffected by Japan fire.
newsitem.headline: Toyota US output unaffected by Japan fire.

text.p: Toyota Motor Corp. said on Wednesday that North American production has not been affected by the weekend fire at a crucial brake parts manufacturer that halted the automaker's assembly operations in Japan.
Toyota officials at the Chicago Auto Show said there are enough parts from Aisin Seiki Co Ltd. enroute to the United States and Canada to allow assembly plants there to operate for about a month.
"The North American plants for the time being are not affected," said Barbara McDaniel, a spokeswoman for Toyota Motor Manufacturing North America.
Toyota's plants in Georgetown, Kentucky, and Cambridge, Ontario, like their counterparts in Japan, depend on brake master cylinders and other parts from Aisin Seiki.
The fire forced Toyota to halt some 30 assembly lines in Japan -- all of its domestic production excluding that of affiliate Daihatsu Motor Co.
The automaker said on Wednesday in Tokyo that it planned to resume normal production by Friday as Aisin Seiki sets up alternate production lines.
Toyota officials in Chicago said the company had no plans to shift any parts enroute to North America back to Japan because of the strength of U.S. consumer demand for Toyota products.
In January, Toyota sales shot up 55.5 percent, with sales of North American built cars rising 90 percent.
In addition, they said Aisin Seiki parts could be shipped to North American plants via air freight in order to avoid production line interruptions.
